definition.value: Molecular or ionic substance formed from two or more elements other than carbon
Is this defined in any other ontology?  Its not in ChEBI as of 2/19/15.
Metadata item that characterizes one aspect of a scientific instrument
The role that an instrument plays in a chemical analysis procedure
Method of analysis that uses a scientific instrument to measure a physical or chemical property of chemical substance
Processes by which a heterogeneous sample is prepared so that becomes a homogeneous sample
The processing of a sample, prior to analysis, that is integral to an analytical instrument
The general class of instrument that this device is an example of
Interference in which the analytical signal is influenced by a different mechanism than the analyte e.g. the formation of non-dissociating species in emission spectroscopy.

Interference by a substance that produces a signal by a similar mechanism to the analyte, which in the given procedure (including the apparatus used) can not be distinguished from the signal given by the analyte. For example, in a colour reaction with an organic ligand by also reacting with the ligand and producing a coloured compound absorbing at the same wavelength as the compound produced by the analyte or in an atomic spectrochemical analysis by absorbing or emitting at the same wavelength as the analyte.
Where a chemical entity acts as in interferring species in the detection of a chemical entity acting as an analyte

A molecular entity with a lifetime appreciably longer than a molecular vibration (corresponding to a local potential energy minimum of depth greater than RT) that is formed (directly or indirectly) from the reactants and reacts further to give (either directly or indirectly) the products of a chemical reaction; also the corresponding chemical species.

A solution of one or more chemical entities that has been produced by dilution of a more concentrated solution and will subsequently be used to make a more dilute intermediate stock or working solution

On a molality basis, Im = 1/2 ∑ m_B z_B^2 where the sum goes over all the ions B. z_B is the charge number of ion B. The ionic strength on a concentration basis is defined analogously Ic = 1/2 ∑ c_B z_B^2.
Measurement of a property of a chemical entity(ies) in a chemical reaction  as a function of time as a way to evaluate the kinetics of the chemical reaction
Material entities that part of a scientific laboratory
A person acting in the managerial role of a laboratory facility
Processes performed in a chemical analysis laboratory for taking portions of a sample

The process of transferring a dissolved substance from one liquid phase to another (immiscible or partially miscible) liquid phase in contact with it. Although extraction, partition and distribution are not synonymous, extraction may replace distribution where appropriate (... when the emphasis is on the analyte(s) being distributed (or extracted). )
Numeric portion of a value reported in scientific notation.  The mantissa as quoted indicates the level of accuracy of a measured value by the number of significant digits reported.
There must be another definition of this
Material entity supplies, consumables, or chemicals used in the performance of scientific research
An individual measured data point of a quantity or quality of a material entity

A description of a property of a system by means of a set of specified rules, that maps the property onto a scale of specified values, by direct or 'mathematical' comparison with specified reference(s). The demand for rules makes 'measurement' a scientific concept in contrast to the mere colloquial sense of 'description'. However, in the present definition, 'measurement' has a wider meaning than given in elementary physics. Even a very incomplete description of, for instance, a patient (at a stated time) has to be given by a set of measurements, that are easier to manage and grasp.
Where an entity plays a role in medicine, health, or related areas
This must be defined elsewhere
A chemical element entity that possess the characteristics of metals, e.g. electrical conductvity, shinyness, ductility etc.

Process by which calibration is performed on a sample where the matrix components cause the signal from the analyte to be enchanced or deminished by the 'matrix effect'.  The same small portion of a sample is added to all calibration solutions so that the matrix is matched, and the analyte concentration is determined by extrapolation of the regression line to  y=0.
Material formed by the mixing of two or more chemical substances
Get definition from Miller and Miller...

Glassware used for the manipulation/containment of chemical substances and mixtures that does not have a level of measurement accuracy necessary to perform chemical analysis, e.g. beakers, graduated cylinders, reflux condenser, funnel, erlenmeyer flask
Basic property measurement device used in a scientific laboratory that is not used for chemical analysis, e.g. pH meter, thermometer, optical microscope
Preparation of a calibration curve using standard solutions made up in a 'clean' matrix, i.e. a solution that is the best for operation of the analytical instrument and/or detection of the analyte.
A representation of the numeric value of a dataum
Table that reports parameters of spectral, chromatographic, or other interprered peaks from a chemical analysis procedure

label.value: Where a chemical entity plays the role of a pharmceutically active agent in pharmaceutical preparation

definition.value: A substance composed of macromolecules.
Identification of the physical quantity a datum is a measurement of
Processes by which mixtures of chemical entities are separated using differences in physical properties

A laboratory-based analytical instrument that has been modified in order to be transported to the location of the sample (as opposed to sample taken to the instrument) in order to perform the chemical analysis

A determination by weight; e.g. in the older method of Cl− ion determination, a weighed amount of sample is dissolved in water, AgNO3 solution added, AgCl is precipitated, dried and weighed. From the known mass fraction of silver in AgCl, the weights of the initial sample and that of the AgCl precipitated, the percentage of chlorine in the sample can be calculated readily. [Listed as gravimetric method in IUPAC Orange book]

The process of using a high capacity thin-layer chromatography plate to separate components of a sample prior to analysis by another technique.  Typically a large amount of sample is loading in one spot or band, the separation allowed to occur, one or more chemical substances removed from the plate by scraping of the solid chromatographic phase, and subsequent extraction of the compound(s) into an appropriate solvent.
Chemical substance used to stabilize the composition of sample prior to analysis.  The intent is to ensure there is no change in analyte chemical entity concentrations prior to analysis.
A primary standard is a substance of known high purity which may be dissolved in a known volume of solvent to give a primary standard solution (having an accurately known concentration).
A chemical entity that acts as a substance of known high purity which may be dissolved in a known volume of solvent to give a primary standard solution (having an accurately known concentration).
An attribute that belongs to an entity and characterizes it in some way
Measurement of a physical or chemical property in order to characterize a substance or material
An analysis where the presence/absence of a chemical substance in a material is determined

The guarantee that the quality of a product (analytical data set, etc.) is actually what is claimed on the basis of the quality control applied in creating that product. Quality assurance is not synonymous with quality control. Quality assurance is meant to protect against failures of quality control.
An analysis where the absolute concentration, relative concentration, or amount of a chemical substance is determined
A chemical entity that acts as a reactant in a chemical reaction
The roles that chemical entities play in chemical reactions

A substance that is consumed in the course of a chemical reaction. It is sometimes known, especially in the older literature, as a reagent, but this term is better used in a more specialized sense as a test substance that is added to a system in order to bring about a reaction or to see whether a reaction occurs (e.g. an analytical reagent).
